column1: Dundalk (  DUN-dawk or  DUN-dok) is an unincorporated community and census-designated place in Baltimore County
column3: United States. The population was 63
column5: Dundalk was the largest unincorporated community in Maryland. It was named after the town of Dundalk
column6: Ireland.  Dundalk is considered one of the first inner-ring suburbs of Baltimore.

column2: the area was occupied by the tribes of the Susquehannock Indians.

column1: Most of Dundalk is flat and very near sea level
column2: with a few small hills close to the city of Baltimore to the west. Dundalk is part of the Atlantic Coastal Plain.  Elevations range from sea level on the shore of the Chesapeake Bay to approximately 40 feet (12 m) above sea level along the northern reaches of Dundalk Avenue and North Point Boulevard.

column1: Bread and Cheese Creek is a tributary of the Back River in Dundalk. The creek is 8.5 miles (13.7 km) long
column2: with headwaters in Baltimore City. It flows through Dundalk before emptying into the Back River
column3: which flows into the Chesapeake Bay. The watershed area of the creek is 1.85 square miles (4.8 km2).

column1: Dundalk contains a campus of the Community College of Baltimore County
column2: known as CCBC-Dundalk. It was formerly known as Dundalk Community College.

column1: For primary and secondary education Dundalk is served by the Baltimore County Public Schools system
column3: Patapsco High School
column4: and Sparrows Point High School being the major high schools to serve the area. Dundalk is also home to Sollers Point Technical High School
